Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Small: Enabling High-Quality Mobile Crowdsourcing with Lifestyle-aware and Energy-efficient Control

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The success of a crowdsourcing application highly depends on whether a capable crowd can be recruited to undertake the corresponding tasks. For most applications, the cost is also a big concern. Recent research has been focused on incentive mechanisms for mobile crowdsourcing, which determine how to recruit a crowd mainly based on their prices/costs. However, scant attention has been paid to capability of the recruited crowd, i.e., the quality of services/data each individual mobile user and the whole crowd are potentially capable of providing. The project team aims to design a new lifestyle-aware approach for mobile crowdsourcing. The basic idea is to maintain a (relatively) stable set of mobile users and learn to gain a comprehensive view of their life patterns (i.e., their capabilities) such that once a mobile crowdsourcing task is received, a good crowd, whose capabilities well match the task, can be quickly found. The proposed research will significantly improve quality of mobile crowdsourcing services and reduce their energy usages, which can substantially benefit mobile crowdsourcing service providers and users, and more importantly, is good for global environment. Moreover, the proposed project is expected to fill the literature gap and inspire more research along this line.

The objective of this project to enable high-quality mobile crowdsourcing by designing a novel and holistic solution for crowd recruitment, which utilizes an energy-efficient framework for learning lifestyles of mobile users via smartphone sensing, and then employs lifestyle-aware algorithms and incentive mechanisms for crowd recruitment. To achieve the above objective, the proposed research is organized into three cohesive research thrusts: Thrust 1 Energy-efficient Lifestyle Learning: a unified and energy-efficient framework will be developed to learn lifestyles of mobile users by characterizing their behaviors and habits, and predicting their future activities; Thrust 2 Lifestyle-aware Crowd Recruitment and Incentive Mechanisms: Quality of Crowd (QoC) models and lifestyle-aware algorithms will be developed for effective crowd recruitment; Thrust 3 Implementation and Performance Evaluation: the proposed approaches will be implemented on a smartphone sensing platform and will be validated and evaluated via extensive simulation and experiments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, the research team aimed to designing a novel and holistic solution for high-quality, lifestyle-aware and secure mobile crowdsourcing. Specifically, the project team, for the first time, built a smartphone sensing based system which energy-efficiently collects features to learn and analyze lifestyles of mobile users based on various context information (collected from smartphones).  They were also the first to leverage the emerging deep learning techniques for spatiotemporal modeling and prediction of mobile users and networks by developing a new hybrid deep neural network model, and showing its effectiveness and superiority with real data.  Moreover, they conducted a comprehensive study for Quality of Crowd (QoC) models and proposed several models for various application scenarios. Based on these models, they proposed a quality-aware and fine-grained incentive mechanism and formally proved it is truthful, individually rational and computationally efficient. In addition, the project team has done extensive work to address privacy and security for mobile crowdsourcing. For example, they, for the first time, formally defined the Sybil attack model in crowdsensing, and proposed two incentive mechanisms for both single-minded and multi-mined cases and proved both of them are Sybil-proof. Moreover, they proposed a truth discovery framework, which is resistant to the Sybil attack and ensures high aggregation accuracy. They also studied the trade-off between location privacy and location quality in mobile crowdsourcing from the optimization perspective, and proposed optimal and near-optimal approximation algorithms for different optimization problems.

        This research has produced 17 papers in premier conferences and journals. The PI and his students delivered presentations and invited talks at numerous conferences and universities. A total of 5 Ph.D students were trained in this project, in which they learned theories and problem-solving skills (including design and analysis of algorithms and auction theory), as well as the state-of-the-art of the emerging technologies (including deep learning, smartphone sensing, mobile  crowdsourcing, security, privacy, etc.). Moreover, they gained hands-on experience on simulation and software development with popular software tools for networking and machine learning research (including PyTorch, TensorFlow, LEDA, Gurobi Optimizer, Matlab, etc).  A female high-school student participated in this project as a summer intern. She learned the basics of auction theory and algorithm design; gained some programming experience, and helped prepare the manuscript for the ICDCS?2016 paper. In addition, research results and findings have been integrated into a graduate course, Cloud Computing.
